author: By Alison Gregor
title: House Hunting in Honduras: A Pastel Palace on Roatán for $579,000
description: The sliver of an island off the Caribbean coast of Honduras has seen its longtime buyer’s market shift to the seller’s side as inventory dwindles.
content: This three-bedroom villa with panoramic Caribbean Sea views commands a high ridge on the northwest coast of Roatán, an island off the northern coast of Honduras.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: A Neil Diamond Musical Is Coming to Broadway, After a Stop in Boston
description: “A Beautiful Noise” will start at Emerson Colonial Theater in Boston next month and transfer to Broadway’s Broadhurst Theater in November.
content: A new musical about the life and career of Neil Diamond is coming to Broadway late this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Doug Mastriano, a far-right 2020 election denier, is Pennsylvania Republicans’ choice for governor.
description: Mr. Mastriano, a retired Army colonel, prevailed over a last-ditch effort by his rivals and state Republican leaders to stop him out of the fear he will be a weak general-election candidate.
content: Doug Mastriano, a central figure in former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election in Pennsylvania, won the state’s Republican primary for governor on Tuesday, making the general election a referendum on democracy in the place where American representative government was born.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Election Deniers Thrive Even as Trumpism Drifts: 5 Primary Takeaways
description: The day’s biggest race, the Republican Senate primary in Pennsylvania, was too close to call. But elsewhere, candidates who dispute the 2020 outcome ran away with G.O.P. contests.
content: Pennsylvania’s Republican Senate contest, the biggest and most expensive race of a five-state primary night, is a photo finish between David McCormick, a former hedge fund executive, and Dr. Mehmet Oz, the celebrity surgeon. It appears headed to a statewide recount.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Jordan Spieth Is Muttering Less and Smiling More
description: And why not? After a couple of years of uncharacteristically mediocre play, he sees an opportunity at the P.G.A. Championship to complete a career Grand Slam.
content: TULSA, Okla. — Sixteen months ago, Jordan Spieth spent long stretches during post-round news conferences answering questions about what was wrong with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ray Scott, Creator of the Super Bowl of Bass Fishing, Dies at 88
description: He turned bass fishing into a professional sport with the championship Bassmaster Classic and other tournaments, using his showmanship skills to excite fans.
content: Ray Scott, an exuberant promoter who turned bass fishing into a professional sport by organizing a series of tournaments that found television homes on TNN and ESPN, died on May 8 in Hayneville, Ala. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: 11 Quick Spring Dinners for Celebrating Warm, Sunny Days
description: Asparagus, rhubarb and peas, peas, peas: The season of abundant produce has finally arrived.
content: Tulips stand tall, farmers’ markets feel more crowded (with produce and people), the sun shines a bit brighter and, oh, your allergies are here: Spring is in full swing. To celebrate, we’ve rounded up some of our lightest, brightest dinners of the season — alongside a few hearty staples, in case it’s still a bit cool where you stay. So grab that asparagus, those peas and that spinach, and get cooking with any of these New York Times Cooking recipes below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: Why Salmon and Rice Go So Well Together
description: With a funky, umami-packed sauce this salmon bowl highlights the old saying: What grows together goes together.
content: It has been years since my mother roasted a salmon head. But I can still hear that tick-tocking toaster oven, a sign of the dish’s imminent arrival at our dinner table. The “head” part of it all was scary to me as a child, but as an adult, I find myself craving the fishy butteriness of the cheek meat, what I call the bone marrow of the sea. Stirred through a bowl of freshly steamed Calrose rice (maybe with a dab of doenjang, that salty dream of a soybean paste), roasted salmon head is easily in my Top 10 favorite things to eat. But without the rice? Not so much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joy Dong
title: China’s Internet Censors Try a New Trick: Revealing Users’ Locations
description: The rapidly expanding practice, which authorities say helps combat disinformation from abroad, has fueled a whole new type of online battle.
content: For years China’s censors have relied on a trusted tool kit to control the country’s internet. They have deleted posts, suspended accounts, blocked keywords, and arrested the most outspoken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: A Panel to Combat Disinformation Becomes a Victim of It
description: The Department of Homeland Security suspended the work of a panel focused on the subject of disinformation. The group had provoked accusations of government overreach.
content: The Department of Homeland Security announced on Wednesday that it was suspending the work of an internal advisory board intended to combat disinformation after what the department described as a deliberate disinformation campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Neil MacFarquhar, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Levenson
title: Russia Uses Surrender in Mariupol to Portray Ukrainians as Terrorists
description: Many soldiers who surrendered from Mariupol’s Azovstal steel plant belong to the Azov battalion, a group with far-right roots, and the Kremlin may now put them on trial just as Ukraine is prosecuting Russians for war crimes.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia seized on the mass surrender of Ukrainian troops at a Mariupol steel plant as a propaganda gift on Wednesday, moving to falsely label them as terrorists and create a parallel narrative to Ukraine’s portrayal of Russian soldiers as heinous war criminals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green and Maya Phillips
title: Against All Odds, Broadway Rose to the Occasion. Mostly.
description: Decoding the Tony nominations, our critics review a season of bold productions that met audiences often craving the familiar.
content: The Broadway season that will be celebrated by the Tony Awards presentation on June 12 began — well, we don’t recall when. It was at least two years and three Covid waves ago. But that doesn’t mean there was nothing worth seeing, loving and arguing about. Far from it, as Jesse Green (the chief theater critic) and Maya Phillips (a critic-at-large) found in recapping the 34 productions that braved the pandemic to open under the most onerous conditions imaginable. Here are excerpts from their conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘Atoms and Ashes,’ a Frightening Tour of Six Nuclear Accidents
description: Serhii Plokhy writes about Three Mile Island, Chernobyl and other disasters, and about the common impulse among governments “to hide information and, later, to spin or distort it.”
content: On Oct. 8, 1957, a Soviet newspaper reported that residents of Cheliabinsk, a city near the Ural Mountains, had spotted an “intensive luminescence, sometimes changing to pale pink and pale blue,” along the horizon. Cheliabinsk was located too far south to have had much experience with the aurora borealis, but the newspaper told its readers they happened to be seeing just that — a rare and gorgeous treat. “The Northern Lights,” the article concluded, “will remain visible in the Southern Ural latitudes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: New Insights Into Long Covid
description: A large new study is telling us more about the condition.
content: A major new study released today has yielded some striking findings about long Covid and its serious impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By B.D. McClay
title: Kim Kardashian Evokes Marilyn Monroe and We Get to Judge
description: The cherished pastime of critiquing celebrities’ red-carpet looks meets a new wrinkle.
content: For its host, the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the annual Met Gala serves a simple purpose: fund-raising. But for those of us who follow the event from home, it is often about something else: judging other people’s clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Tony Awards 2022: Who Will Win (and Who Should)
description: A critic’s picks in a hard-to-predict Broadway year, plus nods to shows from Off Broadway and other, odder corners.
content: Though I see hundreds of shows a year, I’m not a seer. Nor am I the kind of theater lover who easily sorts treasured experiences into tranches of good, better and best. Nevertheless, here I am with prognostications and preferences for the Tony Awards that will be given out on June 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Neil Vigdor
title: Who Won, Who Lost and Which Races Haven’t Been Called Yet
description: Nobody declared victory in Pennsylvania’s Republican Senate primary, despite a Trump endorsement. Representative Madison Cawthorn of North Carolina was ousted after a series of scandals.
content: The marquee election on Tuesday evening, the Republican Senate primary in Pennsylvania, is going down to the wire, but consequential races were decided, setting up general election matchups for the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Bradley
title: Labour asks if Conservatives broke U.K. election laws by accepting a donation linked to a Russian account.
description: Britain’s opposition Labour Party on Tuesday formally demanded answers in Parliament to whether the governing Conservative Party had breached electoral laws when it accepted a major political donation that documents link to a Russian bank account. Opposition leaders also asked for information about the donor’s potential ties to the Kremlin.
content: Britain’s opposition Labour Party on Tuesday formally demanded answers in Parliament to whether the governing Conservative Party had breached electoral laws when it accepted a major political donation that documents link to a Russian bank account. Opposition leaders also asked for information about the donor’s potential ties to the Kremlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley, Jonah E. Bromwich and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Hochul Vows to Crack Down on Extremist Acts of Violence in New York
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul issued orders to strengthen the state’s “red-flag” law and create new units to target violent extremism online, following the Buffalo shooting that left 10 dead.
content: Days after a deadly mass shooting at a supermarket in Buffalo, Gov. Kathy Hochul on Wednesday took a series of aggressive steps to strengthen New York’s gun laws and to investigate the social media platforms where the suspected gunman was radicalized and where the police say he streamed his racist attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Even glittering Cannes can’t avoid the war in Ukraine.
description: At the film festival on the French Riviera, official Russian delegates have been barred from attending and President Volodymyr Zelensky made an appearance.
content: The war in Ukraine is casting a long shadow over this year’s Cannes Film Festival. On Tuesday, Volodymyr Zelensky, the country’s president, addressed the event’s opening ceremony, with stirring rhetoric and Charlie Chaplin quotes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Relatives Charged in Exorcism Death of 3-Year-Old Girl
description: The child died from asphyxiation at a Pentecostal church in San Jose, Calif., as her mother, uncle and grandfather tried to expel what they believed was an “evil spirit,” the authorities said.
content: The mother, uncle and grandfather of a 3-year-old girl smothered her during a daylong exorcism at a church in San Jose, Calif., the authorities said last week, announcing charges in an investigation that began with the girl’s death in September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Men, Share Your Stories About Abortion
description: Have you been in the position of supporting or objecting to a woman’s decision to end a pregnancy?
content: The Times is looking for men based in the United States to share their stories about experiences with abortion. Have you been in the position of supporting or objecting to a woman’s decision to end a pregnancy? How did your personal experience shape the way you feel about abortion and abortion access today?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Kate Kelly
title: Melvin Capital, hedge fund torpedoed by the GameStop frenzy, is shutting down.
description: The firm lost billions of dollars as it scrambled to cover its bets against the video game retailer that became a darling of retail traders.
content: Melvin Capital, the hedge fund run by Gabe Plotkin that struggled with heavy losses last year as it reeled from wrong-way bets on GameStop, is shutting down, according to a letter sent to investors on Wednesday that was reviewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: Veronica Ryan’s Uncanny Objects
description: At 65, the British artist based in New York is in the Whitney Biennial and on the Turner Prize shortlist. Her sculptures blend strange and common items to make sense of the world.
content: A soursop. A breadfruit. A custard apple. Incongruously large but otherwise realistic, the three sculptures of tropical fruit sit right on the ground in a busy pedestrian plaza in the Hackney section of London, as if the produce had tumbled from a grocer’s stand and magically expanded on the pavement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California’s Immersive Art Exhibits Worth Visiting
description: Exhibits include Glenn Kaino’s new show in Los Angeles and the mainstay “Sensorio” in Paso Robles.
content: Perhaps, as our interactions are more and more mediated by screens, you’re seeking to immerse yourself in the tangible world, to awaken all your senses. Or, maybe, you just want a cool photo for social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: The Digital Tools That Aided the Buffalo Gunman — and What to Do About Them
description: Wesley Lowery and Jared Holt discuss how people get stuck on “sticky floors of the extremism cave online” — and what platforms ought to do about it.
content: A shooter, radicalized online, plotted a racist attack with plenty of digital fingerprints, intended to livestream it on social media and published a manifesto online. It happened in Christchurch, New Zealand, in 2019. And it seems to have happened again last week in Buffalo. In the years in between, we’ve heard plenty about social media companies amping up their content moderation efforts and clamping down on violent extremism. Yet nothing — or not enough — has really changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Crafting a Rom-Com That’s True to 21st-Century Gay Life
description: Billy Eichner and the “Bros” team made news by casting queer actors, but they also focused on writing a story that didn’t recycle straight tropes.
content: On a brisk November day, in a wing of the Newark Museum of Art mocked up as the first New York museum dedicated to L.G.B.T.Q. history, Billy Eichner stood in front of a glass vitrine. Inside was a black-and-white image of Magnus Hirschfeld, a Weimar-era physician and sexologist. In character as Bobby, the museum’s chief curator, Eichner gave a brief precis of Hirschfeld’s career, finishing with an ad-lib, “Tragically, he’s also my type.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: What is Un Certain Regard?
description: The festival’s largest sidebar of new films is about looking to new horizons and filmmakers.
content: Cannes’s sidebars and parallel festivals kick off today (other than Cannes Classics, which opened yesterday with a restoration of “The Mother and the Whore.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: The surrender of Ukrainian forces in Mariupol.
content: Hundreds of Ukrainian soldiers from the Azovstal steel mill in Mariupol who had made a last stand against Russian forces are now in the Kremlin’s custody and have been transported to Russian-held territory after Ukraine’s military ordered them to surrender. Russian officials have raised the prospect that at least some may be treated as war criminals. Follow the latest updates from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: How U.S. Soccer and Its Players Solved the Equal Pay Puzzle
description: New contracts for the men’s and women’s national teams will usher in an era of equal pay at U.S. Soccer. Here’s how it will work.
content: The new collective bargaining agreements approved this week by the United States Soccer Federation and its men’s and women’s national teams will, at last, bring an end to a decades-long, emotionally exhausting and wildly expensive fight over equal pay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Kansas Supreme Court Allows Republican Voting Map to Stand
description: A lower court had declared the map an unconstitutional gerrymander. The ruling could cost Democrats a seat in Congress.
content: WASHINGTON — The Kansas Supreme Court on Wednesday allowed the state to adopt a new congressional map that a lower court had ruled unconstitutional, handing a victory to Republicans and very likely costing the state’s Democrats their only seat in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross, David F. Gallagher and Anna Schaverien
title: Big Tech Takes Texas to the Supreme Court
description: Social network companies want to block a Texas law that restricts content moderation.
content: Violent videos like the livestream of last weekend’s mass shooting in Buffalo, N.Y., have long been a problem for social media sites. Such atrocities always stir up national debate about the responsibilities of social media companies to block harmful material. This time, the debate is happening amid a messy fight about free speech that the companies are taking to the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: At Cannes, a case for movies in a TikTok world.
description: Our reporter reflects on his first night at the Cannes Film Festival, an event that can sometimes seem like a throwback to an earlier age.
content: CANNES, France — When Jeff Nichols first attended the Cannes Film Festival, he was a 21-year-old college student interning at the event’s American Pavilion. His days were mostly spent waiting tables, but every so often, Nichols got his hands on a premiere ticket, donned a tuxedo that his mother had bought him, and took a seat high in the balcony of the Grand Théâtre Lumière. Whenever he landed there, he felt he was at the summit of everything he wanted to do in life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: 70 N.Y. Judges Went on a Montauk Retreat. 20 Came Down With the Virus.
description: A judicial gathering at a seaside resort, with karaoke included, became a superspreader event.
content: More than 70 New York City judges descended on a Long Island resort last week to enjoy an annual three-night retreat. In the days after, 20 tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: You Shouldn’t Need a Doctor’s Note to Switch Formula Brands
description: The formula shortage is temporary. Changes to WIC should be permanent.
content: On Wednesday, responding to the baby formula shortage crisis, President Biden said he is invoking the Defense Production Act “to ensure that manufacturers have the necessary ingredients to make safe, healthy infant formula here at home.” He also announced something called Operation Fly Formula “to speed up the import of infant formula and start getting more formula in stores as soon as possible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: John L. Canley, Belated Medal of Honor Recipient, Dies at 84
description: He was the first living Black Marine to be awarded America’s highest military decoration — 50 years after he demonstrated valor in Vietnam.
content: Sgt. Maj. John L. Canley, who rescued more than 20 fellow Marines under enemy fire in Vietnam in 1968 and, 50 years later, became the first living Black Marine to be awarded the Medal of Honor, died on May 11 in Bend, Ore. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christie Aschwanden
title: How to Master the Push-Up
description: With proper technique, you can get the most out of this simple, yet powerful exercise.
content: Simple, strenuous and possible to do almost anywhere, push-ups are an almost universally known exercise and a mainstay of military, sport and fitness training regimens. Push-ups are a “basic, foundational movement,” said James Whitener III, a strength and conditioning coach at Bethune-Cookman University in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Wants to Follow China’s Covid ‘Success.’ Its Plan May Backfire.
description: As infections spread quickly, outside experts are warning that the country’s desire to mimic Beijing’s playbook could worsen a coming disaster.
content: SEOUL — When North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, acknowledged an outbreak of Covid-19 last week, he ordered his government to learn from ​China’s “success” fighting the virus​.​ ​What he did not say is that an attempt to follow China’s pandemic response could send his impoverished country toward catastrophe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Woman Led Unemployment Fraud Ring From Prison, Prosecutors Say
description: A California prison worker helped Natalie Le DeMola, who is serving a life sentence for murder, in the fraud scheme, officials said.
content: A California woman serving a life prison sentence for murder led a scheme to collect at least $2 million in unemployment benefits using stolen identities, including those of other incarcerated people, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: Nuri Bilge Ceylan’s Masterpiece of Existential Angst
description: His moody 2004 film, ‘Distant,’ about an unemployed factory worker in Istanbul, has been revived for a short run at Film Forum in Manhattan.
content: The miracle of Nuri Bilge Ceylan’s “Distant” is that it is continually absorbing, even when not much is happening — which is most of the time. A photographer before he became the dean of Turkish filmmakers, Ceylan is a master of existential angst and transfigured dailiness whose movies invite contemplation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: In Buffalo, Biden Denounces ‘Domestic Terrorism’
description: The president acknowledged that it would be difficult to persuade Congress to act on restricting guns.
content: Good morning. Today we’ll follow the developments in Buffalo, where President Biden joined in the mourning for victims of the supermarket massacre. We’ll also look at how new congressional district maps would pit some New York Democrats against each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Erin Griffith
title: How a Trash-Talking Crypto Founder Caused a $40 Billion Crash
description: Do Kwon, a South Korean entrepreneur, hyped the Luna and TerraUSD cryptocurrencies. Their failures have devastated some traders, though not the investment firms that cashed out early.
content: Do Kwon, a trash-talking entrepreneur from South Korea, called the cryptocurrency he created in 2018 “my greatest invention.” In countless tweets and interviews, he trumpeted the world-changing potential of the currency, Luna, rallying a band of investors and supporters he proudly referred to as “Lunatics.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: Poppers, Once a Fixture at Gay Clubs, Now a ‘Party Girl’ Favorite
description: A new generation is experimenting with the disco-era inhalants.
content: The party blogger and aspiring “It” girl known as Meg Superstar Princess was at Rash, a club with a tiny dance floor in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn in March, when someone spilled a bottle of alkyl nitrites — better known as “poppers” — on the dance floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: America’s Doug Mastriano Problem
description: The Republican Party’s strategy to contain populist rebellion didn’t work in Pennsylvania.
content: If the Ohio Senate primary two weeks ago provided some clarity about the ideological divisions in the Republican Party, Tuesday’s primaries often seemed more like a showcase for the distinctive personalities that populate a Trumpified G.O.P.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
title: For Hochul, Shooting in Buffalo Is a Hometown Tragedy
description: The governor grew up in the Buffalo suburbs and lives in the city now. The shooting has taken on political overtones in the 2022 race for governor of New York.
content: Hours after an 18-year-old gunman killed 10 people in a Buffalo supermarket, Gov. Kathy Hochul convened a news conference just blocks away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Angel
title: Catskill, N.Y.: A Place Where ‘People Are Jazzed About Making Art’
description: The Greene County town and the eponymous village at its heart have long drawn creative types. But now there’s a fresh influx from the city.
content: Rob Spillman and Elissa Schappell closed on their Catskill, N.Y., house, an 1840s farmhouse on 6.4 acres, in the middle of an ice storm in February. “We had to keep stopping to get the ice off the windshield wipers,” said Mr. Spillman, 57, a literary consultant and freelance writer who founded the now-defunct literary magazine “Tin House” with Ms. Schappell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: French company to face charges of complicity in human rights violations.
description: Lafarge faces a court battle over allegations that it put employees at risk and financed terrorist groups in a bid to keep operating in Syria.
content: A French court issued a precedent-setting ruling Wednesday that will allow Lafarge, one of France’s biggest companies, to be charged with aiding and abetting crimes against humanity after it was accused of financing terrorist groups, including the Islamic State, while operating in Syria during the country’s bloody civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Former Minneapolis Officer Pleads Guilty in George Floyd Case
description: Thomas Lane entered the plea in state court to a charge of second-degree manslaughter, Minnesota’s attorney general said.
content: A former Minneapolis police officer, Thomas Lane, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to a second-degree manslaughter charge in the death of George Floyd in 2020, Minnesota’s attorney general said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: ‘I could not stay away’: With Russians pushed back, residents return to Kharkiv.
description: Family members clutched one another in joy at Kharkiv railway station on Tuesday as relatives who had fled the bombardment of the city arrived on the train from the capital, Kyiv.
content: Family members clutched one another in joy at Kharkiv railway station on Tuesday as relatives who had fled the bombardment of the city arrived on the train from the capital, Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Lawmaker Reportedly Arrested Over Rape Allegations
description: The arrest, of a man who has not yet been identified, was the latest in a string of sexual misconduct allegations against members of Parliament.
content: LONDON — A British lawmaker was arrested on Tuesday on suspicion of rape and other sexual assault offenses, according to British news media reports, the latest in a string of sexual misconduct allegations against members of Parliament in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Woman Whose Voice Was Heard in Surfside Rubble Is Identified
description: After a lengthy investigation, Miami-Dade officials say the trapped woman was Theresa Velasquez, 36, a music executive from Los Angeles who was visiting her parents. They also died.
content: It was five hours after the collapse of a 13-story beachfront condominium building in Surfside, Fla., last June when rescue crews first heard a woman’s voice coming from under the rubble. It was faint but calm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The world is as vulnerable as ever to pandemics, an expert panel concludes.
description: The authors of the new report zeroed in on the uneven distribution of vaccines around the world as one of the major hurdles to overcome.
content: Governments around the world are no better prepared today to address a new global disease threat than they were just before the coronavirus outbreak began in late 2019, a World Health Organization panel concluded in a report released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bittel
title: Watch a Giant Stingray’s Safe Return to Its River Home
description: The Mekong River is home to enormous and endangered aquatic life. A 400-pound fish’s release shows how some conservation efforts in Cambodia are paying off.
content: Just after dawn on May 5, scientists working along a stretch of the Mekong River in Cambodia released a giant, endangered freshwater stingray that had been caught on a fisherman’s line. At 13 feet long and 400 pounds, the gigantic animal pancake was larger than a hibachi table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Ashley Biden, President Biden’s daughter, and Xavier Becerra, the health secretary, test positive for the virus.
description: Neither is considered a close contact to the first couple, according to the administration.
content: Xavier Becerra, the U.S. secretary of health and human services, tested positive for the coronavirus on Wednesday, his department said, hours after the White House announced that Ashley Biden, the daughter of President Biden and the first lady, Jill Biden, had tested positive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden Health Officials Warn of Substantial Increase in Virus Cases
description: The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urged local leaders and individuals to at least consider returning to wearing masks in indoor public settings.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal health officials warned on Wednesday that a third of Americans live in areas where the threat of Covid-19 is now so high that they should consider wearing a mask in indoor public settings. They cited new data showing a substantial jump in both the spread of the coronavirus and hospitalizations over the past week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Inflation in Britain hits 9 percent, the fastest pace in four decades.
description: The annual inflation rate jumped as household gas and electricity bills rose significantly.
content: Britain’s annual inflation rate jumped to 9 percent last month, the highest in 40 years, the Office for National Statistics said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Strongmen in Turkey and Hungary Stall Unity in NATO and the E.U.
description: Russia benefits as Turkey slows down Swedish and Finnish applications to NATO and Hungary continues to block an E.U. embargo on Russian oil.
content: BRUSSELS — Europe’s effort to stand up to Russia and Vladimir V. Putin, its president, is being slowed by two strongmen leaders insisting on the priority of their national interests and playing to domestic audiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Hua
title: Forget About Perfection. Embrace ‘Mamahuhu.’
description: The Chinese expression became my family’s motto for the haphazard nature of living on the margins.
content: As a kid, I spoke English to my Chinese immigrant parents, who replied to me and my siblings mostly in kind. My grandmother, who lived with us, was different. She could communicate to us only in Mandarin; what we couldn’t understand in words, we’d figure out through pantomime. A few phrases in Mandarin are particularly vivid to me — the ones my parents used when they grumbled about something: hulihutu, or “muddle-headed”; fa feng, or “to go crazy”; and most striking of all, mamahuhu, which means “so-so” or “mediocre” (and also “careless”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Judge Faults Medical Care for Detainees in Latest Sign of Rikers Crisis
description: The ruling came the same day that city officials delivered a plan for potentially avoiding a federal takeover of the troubled jail complex.
content: A state judge ruled on Tuesday that New York City’s Correction Department had failed to provide detainees with timely medical care. The ruling came the same day that city officials and a federal monitor produced a plan to potentially avoid a federal takeover of the troubled Rikers Island jail complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
